repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment shows a satisfactory
            project outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, accompanied by
            satisfactory performances both by the Bank and Borrower. The
            following lessons emerged from the experience of the
            project. Conditionality in an adjustment operation: The
            large number of conditions for project effectiveness and
            second tranche release will need to be balanced with the
            implementing capacity of the borrower. In Mongolia, this
            presented a serious challenge to the government, and as
            well, for maintaining the momentum and the continuous
            attention it required, particularly in light of
            Administration changes. This was reflected in the weak
            capacity, and lack of information among government agencies.
            This requires a technical assistance operation in capacity
            building programs, to prepare the ground for, or a technical
            assistance operation in parallel with, the adjustment
            operation. A key to ensure fulfillment of tranche release
            conditions is the Bank team/management's continuous
            dialogue with the main stakeholders on the longer-term
            benefits of difficult policy actions required by the
            adjustment lending. In addition, an appropriate time frame
            is required for the institution-building components,
            particularly so in countries with weak civil service such as
            Mongolia. The time frame required to introduce fundamental
            changes in the financial and banking sectors, as well as for
            institution building, requires better programming and
            sequencing. Therefore, new institutions, once established,
            would need continuing monitoring and improvement in order to
            be effective in fulfilling their role in the financial sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Adjustment Credit
            Project, will support the Government's medium-term
            strategy for financial sector reform, in order to achieve
            macroeconomic stability, accelerate private sector growth,
            and reduce poverty. The components include the establishment
            of basic financial infrastructure, such as improved banking
            skills, accounting standards, and clear policy framework
            regarding bank failures; consolidation of the banking
            system; divestiture of the Government's ownership in
            the Trade and Development Bank; development of effective
            regulation, and supervision of the financial system;
            improvement of the payments system in rural areas; and,
            confirmation of the government's commitment to honor
            financial contracts, through a timely servicing of
            Government bonds. Within the strategic framework, the
            project will provide financial resources to Mongolia, and
            avoid excessive transitional decline in consumption, and
            investment practices, enabling a reasonable adjustment to
            recent trade shocks. The economy will benefit from the
            emergence of institutions, and markets, thus,
            inter-mediation of financial resources will be ensured.
            However, the outcome of the forthcoming parliamentary
            elections may hinder ownership of the financial sector
            program, and, the limitations within the administrative
            capacity, may be further weakened by the opposition of
            vested interests.
